message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Proceedings of the 30th International Conference on Intelligent User Interfaces
Paper Abstract: user interfaces mediate between person and machine to increase the ease and effectiveness of user interactions. Research in intelligent user interfaces draws on areas such as artificial and human-computer interaction to study methods for supporting varied users for a wide range of tasks, task environments, platforms, and interaction paradigms. The IUI conference is the annual meeting of the intelligent interfaces community, and serves as the principal international forum for reporting outstanding research and development in intelligent user interfaces. IUI'03, the Seventh IUI, was held at The Palms South Beach hotel in Miami Beach, Florida, USA, from January 12-15, 2003. special theme of the conference was highlighting interfaces whose focus goes beyond rational intelligence to address psychological concerns such as emotion, personality, and motivationIUI'03 solicited submissions in three categories, long papers, describing mature work; short papers, describing work in progress, and brief abstracts of system demonstrations. The conference received 134 submissions, an all-time record, including 80 long papers and 49 short papers. Based on rigorous review by an international program committee, 28 papers were selected for oral presentation, with 45 additional submissions featured as posters and demonstrations. Oral presentations spanned the areas of adaptive and collaborative interfaces, affective interfaces, agent-based interfaces, knowledge acquisition and visualization, model-based interface design, multimodal input, and natural language interfacesThe conference program highlighted three invited talks: Daniel Weld presented What Users Want, Hiroshi Ishii presented Tangible Bits: Designing the Seamless Interface between People, Bits, and Atoms, and Allen Gorin presented Semantic Information Processing of Spoken Language in 'How May I Help You?'  (sm). The panel A Life without Friction: Tales from the InfoLab, chaired by Kristian Hammond and Larry Birnbaum, gave an in-depth view of IUI research at the Information Laboratory of Northwestern University, and the panel XML: The Lingua Franca of IUIs?, chaired by Angel Puerta, examined the role of standardization of interoperation and data interchange in the IUI software industry. The conference opened with two tutorials, Intelligent User Interfaces: An Introduction, by Mark Maybury, and Recommender Systems: Interfaces and Technology, by John Riedl and Joseph Konstan
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's an overview of Natural Language Processing based on the search results:

## What is Natural Language Processing?

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer, and it is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is a computer activity in which computers analyze, understand, alter, or generate natural language, including automation of linguistic forms such as conversation, correspondence, reading, writing, translation, and more.

## Major Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

## History and Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Until the 1980s, most NLP systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

## Related Fields

NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

Here's an overview of Natural Language Processing based on the search results:

## What is Natural Language Processing?

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer, and it is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is a computer activity in which computers analyze, understand, alter, or generate natural language, including automation of linguistic forms such as conversation, correspondence, reading, writing, translation, and more.

## Major Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

## History and Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Until the 1980s, most NLP systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

## Related Fields

NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of knowledge visualization:

## Definition

Knowledge visualization focuses on transferring insights and creating new knowledge by further transferring insights, experiences, attitudes, values, expectations, perspectives, opinions, and estimates in different fields using various complementary visualizations.

## Purpose and Function

The use of visual representations to transfer knowledge between people aims to improve the transfer of knowledge by using computer and non-computer-based visualization methods complementarily, making properly designed visualization an important part of both data analysis and the knowledge transfer process.

## Related Fields

Knowledge visualization is connected to several other visualization disciplines:

- Data and information visualization is the practice of designing and creating graphic or visual representations of data and information with static, dynamic or interactive visual items, intended to help audiences visually explore and discover, and gain important insights into structures, relationships, patterns, and trends within data.

- Visual analytics is a multidisciplinary science and technology field that emerged from information visualization and scientific visualization, focusing on how analytical reasoning can be facilitated by interactive visual interfaces.

## Visual Formats

Examples of visual formats used in knowledge visualization include sketches, diagrams, images, objects, interactive visualizations, information visualization applications, and imaginary visualizations as in stories.

Moran - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_P._Moran"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Human-Computer Interaction:

## Definition and Purpose

Human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems.(no content)Research in HCI covers the design and the use of computer technology, which focuses on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.(no content)The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".

## Multidisciplinary Nature

HCI studies a human and a machine in communication, drawing from supporting knowledge on both sides—on the machine side, techniques in computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages, and development environments are relevant, and on the human side, communication theory, graphic and industrial design disciplines, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, social psychology, and human factors are relevant.

## Key Aspects

A key aspect of HCI is user satisfaction, also referred to as End-User Computing Satisfaction.(no content)The interface between humans and computers is crucial to facilitating this interaction.

## Interaction Techniques

Modern HCI involves various interaction methods, including gesture recognition, which involves identifying and interpreting gestures made by users, often used for direct interaction with computers in command and action scenarios, and gaze detection (eye-movement tracking), which involves tracking the movement of a user's eyes and is primarily used to better understand the user's attention, intent, or focus in context-sensitive situations.

Human-Computer Interaction remains a vital field for creating more effective and user-friendly technologies.

Links: [{"title":"Affective computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_computing"},{"title":"Category:Affective computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Affective_computing"},{"title":"Affective design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_design"},{"title":"Rosalind Picard - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosalind_Picard"},{"title":"Talk:Affective computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Affective_computing"},{"title":"Affective haptics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_haptics"},{"title":"Kismet (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kismet_(robot)"},{"title":"Affect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect"},{"title":"Artificial empathy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_empathy"},{"title":"Emotions in virtual communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotions_in_virtual_communication"}]

## Affective Computing - Search Results

I found comprehensive information about affective computing. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Overview
Affective computing is the study and development of systems and devices that can recognize, interpret, process, and simulate human affects.(no content)It is an interdisciplinary field spanning computer science, psychology, and cognitive science.

### History and Origins
The modern branch of computer science originated with Rosalind Picard's 1995 paper entitled "Affective Computing" and her 1997 book of the same name published by MIT Press.(no content)One of the motivations for the research is the ability to give machines emotional intelligence, including to simulate empathy.

### Key Technologies and Methods
Machine learning techniques process different modalities, such as speech recognition, natural language processing, or facial expression detection. For example, speech analysis is an effective method of identifying affective state, having an average reported accuracy of 70 to 80% in research from 2003 and 2006.

### Objective and Applications
The machine should interpret the emotional state of humans and adapt its behavior to them, giving an appropriate response to those emotions.(no content)Decision-making, brand loyalty, and consumer connections have all been associated with the integration of affective design.

The search results demonstrate that affective computing is a rapidly evolving field with applications ranging from human-computer interaction to healthcare and marketing.

## Affective Computing - Search Results

I found comprehensive information about affective computing. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Overview
Affective computing is the study and development of systems and devices that can recognize, interpret, process, and simulate human affects.(no content)It is an interdisciplinary field spanning computer science, psychology, and cognitive science.

### History and Origins
The modern branch of computer science originated with Rosalind Picard's 1995 paper entitled "Affective Computing" and her 1997 book of the same name published by MIT Press.(no content)One of the motivations for the research is the ability to give machines emotional intelligence, including to simulate empathy.

### Key Technologies and Methods
Machine learning techniques process different modalities, such as speech recognition, natural language processing, or facial expression detection. For example, speech analysis is an effective method of identifying affective state, having an average reported accuracy of 70 to 80% in research from 2003 and 2006.

### Objective and Applications
The machine should interpret the emotional state of humans and adapt its behavior to them, giving an appropriate response to those emotions.(no content)Decision-making, brand loyalty, and consumer connections have all been associated with the integration of affective design.

The search results demonstrate that affective computing is a rapidly evolving field with applications ranging from human-computer interaction to healthcare and marketing.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of multimodal interaction:

## Definition

Multimodal human-computer interaction refers to the "interaction with the virtual and physical environment through natural modes of communication", enabling more free and natural communication between users and automated systems in both input and output.

## Key Characteristics

Multimodal systems allow users to interact through input modalities such as speech, handwriting, hand gesture and gaze, and to receive information through output modalities such as speech synthesis, smart graphics and other modalities, opportunely combined.(no content)The advantage of multiple input modalities is increased usability: the weaknesses of one modality are offset by the strengths of another.

## Common Modalities

The most common multimodal interface combines a visual modality (such as a display, keyboard, and mouse) with a voice modality (speech recognition for input, speech synthesis and recorded audio for output).(no content)Other modalities, such as pen-based input or haptic input/output may also be used.

## System Processing

A multimodal system must recognize inputs from different modalities, combining them according to temporal and contextual constraints to allow their interpretation. This process is known as multimodal fusion.

## Research and Applications

Multimodal user interfaces are a research area in human-computer interaction (HCI).

Web search results for query: "Software agent"

Links: [{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Agent-oriented software engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_software_engineering"},{"title":"Comparison of platforms for software agents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_platforms_for_software_agents"},{"title":"Lisp-based Intelligent Software Agents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lisp-based_Intelligent_Software_Agents"},{"title":"Agent-oriented programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_programming"},{"title":"Category:Agent-based software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Agent-based_software"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Management agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Management_agent"},{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"}]

Here are the search results for "Software agent":

## Definition

In computer science, a software agent is a computer program that acts for a user or another program in a relationship of agency.(no content)The concept of an agent provides a convenient and powerful way to describe a complex software entity that is capable of acting with a certain degree of autonomy in order to accomplish tasks on behalf of its host.

## Types and Variants

Related and derived concepts include intelligent agents (in particular exhibiting some aspects of artificial intelligence, such as reasoning), autonomous agents (capable of modifying the methods of achieving their objectives), distributed agents (being executed on physically distinct computers), multi-agent systems (distributed agents that work together to achieve an objective that could not be accomplished by a single agent acting alone), and mobile agents (agents that can relocate their execution onto different processors).

## Benefits and Applications

Software agents may offer various benefits to their end users by automating complex or repetitive tasks. In modern contexts, AI agents (also referred to as compound AI systems) are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments. Agentic AI tools prioritize decision-making over content creation and do not require human prompts or continuous oversight. They possess several key attributes, including complex goal structures, natural language interfaces, the capacity to act independently of user supervision, and the integration of software tools or planning systems.

## Implementation

Software agents are implemented as independent threads which communicate with each other using agent communication languages.

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Timeline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence visual art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_art"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence films - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_films"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

I've successfully performed the web search for "Artificial intelligence." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

## History

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Key Research Areas

The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.(no content)To reach these goals, AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

## Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)

Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

## Applications

AI has widespread applications across various industries, from healthcare and architecture to military operations, astronomy, and creative fields like music and visual art generation.

Would you like more information about any specific aspect of artificial intelligence?

I've successfully performed the web search for "Artificial intelligence." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

## History

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Key Research Areas

The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.(no content)To reach these goals, AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

## Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)

Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

## Applications

AI has widespread applications across various industries, from healthcare and architecture to military operations, astronomy, and creative fields like music and visual art generation.

Would you like more information about any specific aspect of artificial intelligence?

Links: [{"title":"Category:Recommender systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Recommender_systems"},{"title":"Matrix factorization (recommender systems) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_factorization_(recommender_systems)"},{"title":"Recommender system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recommender_system"},{"title":"Knowledge-based recommender system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge-based_recommender_system"},{"title":"Cold start (recommender systems) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cold_start_(recommender_systems)"},{"title":"ACM Conference on Recommender Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ACM_Conference_on_Recommender_Systems"},{"title":"Collaborative filtering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_filtering"},{"title":"Talk:ACM Conference on Recommender Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft_talk:ACM_Conference_on_Recommender_Systems"},{"title":"GroupLens Research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GroupLens_Research"},{"title":"Location-based recommendation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Location-based_recommendation"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of recommender systems:

## Definition and Purpose

A recommender system, also called a recommendation algorithm, recommendation engine, or recommendation platform, is a type of information filtering system that suggests items most relevant to a particular user.(no content)The value of these systems becomes particularly evident in scenarios where users must select from a large number of options, such as products, media, or content, and major social media platforms and streaming services rely on recommender systems that employ machine learning to analyze user behavior and preferences.

## Main Approaches

Recommender systems usually make use of either or both collaborative filtering and content-based filtering, as well as other systems such as knowledge-based systems.

- **Collaborative Filtering**: Collaborative filtering approaches build a model from a user's past behavior (e.g., items previously purchased or selected and/or numerical ratings given to those items) as well as similar decisions made by other users, and this model is then used to predict items that the user may have an interest in.

- **Content-Based Filtering**: Content-based filtering approaches utilize a series of discrete, pre-tagged characteristics of an item in order to recommend additional items with similar properties.

- **Knowledge-Based Systems**: Knowledge-based recommender systems are a specific type of recommender system that are based on explicit knowledge about the item assortment, user preferences, and recommendation criteria.

## Applications

The suggestions typically refer to a variety decision-making processes, including the selection of a product, musical selection, or online news source to read, and the implementation of recommender systems is pervasive, with commonly recognised examples including the generation of playlist for video and music services and the provision of product recommendations for e-commerce platforms.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about information visualization:

## Definition and Purpose

Data and information visualization (data viz/vis or info viz/vis) is the practice of designing and creating graphic or visual representations of quantitative and qualitative data and information with the help of static, dynamic or interactive visual items.(no content)These visualizations are intended to help a target audience visually explore and discover, quickly understand, interpret and gain important insights into otherwise difficult-to-identify structures, relationships, correlations, local and global patterns, trends, variations, constancy, clusters, outliers and unusual groupings within data.

## Key Characteristics

Information visualization concentrates on the use of computer-supported tools to explore large amount of abstract data.(no content)Important aspects of information visualization are dynamics of visual representation and the interactivity. Strong techniques enable the user to modify the visualization in real-time, thus affording unparalleled perception of patterns and structural relations in the abstract data in question.

## Visual Formats

The visual formats used in data visualization include charts and graphs, geospatial maps, figures, correlation matrices, percentage gauges, etc.(no content)Visual tools used include maps for location based data; hierarchical organisations of data; displays that prioritise relationships such as Sankey diagrams; flowcharts, timelines.

## Interdisciplinary Nature

Data and information visualization is interdisciplinary, it incorporates principles found in descriptive statistics, visual communication, graphic design, cognitive science and, interactive computer graphics and human-computer interaction. Since effective visualization requires design skills, statistical skills and computing skills, it is both an art and a science.

Here are the search results for "Speech recognition":

## Overview

Speech recognition (automatic speech recognition (ASR), computer speech recognition, or speech-to-text (STT)) is a sub-field of computational linguistics concerned with methods and technologies that translate spoken language into text or other interpretable forms.

## Historical Development

Applications for speech recognition developed over many decades, with progress accelerated due to advances in deep learning and the use of big data. Some key milestones include:

- 1952 – Bell Labs researchers built Audrey for single-speaker digit recognition.
- 1962 – IBM's 16-word "Shoebox" machine's speech recognition debuted at the 1962 World's Fair.
- By the mid-1980s, Fred Jelinek's team at IBM created a voice-activated typewriter called Tangora, which could handle a 20,000-word vocabulary.
- Sphinx-II was the first to do speaker-independent, large vocabulary, continuous speech recognition, and it won DARPA's 1992 evaluation.

## Modern Approaches

At around the 2010s, deep neural network approaches became more common for speech recognition models, which were enabled by the availability of large datasets ("big data") and increased computational performance.

## Applications

Speech recognition technology is widely used in many applications, including Apple's personal assistant Siri, originally implemented in the iPhone 4S, and Cortana, Microsoft's personal assistant built into Windows Phone and Windows 10.

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_user_interface"},{"title":"History of adaptive automated instruction in computer applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_automated_adaptive_instruction_in_computer_applications"},{"title":"Talk:Adaptive user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Adaptive_user_interface"},{"title":"Adaptive hypermedia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_hypermedia"},{"title":"Adaptive learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_learning"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Attentive user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attentive_user_interface"},{"title":"Adaptive web design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_web_design"},{"title":"User interface modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_interface_modeling"},{"title":"Outline of human–computer interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_human-computer_interaction_topics"}]

## Search Results for "Adaptive Interface"

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about adaptive interfaces:

### Definition

An adaptive user interface (also known as AUI) is a user interface (UI) which adapts, that is changes, its layout and elements to the needs of the user or context and is similarly alterable by each user.

### Key Features

The advantages of an adaptive user interface are found within its ability to conform to a users needs, allowing the properties of an AUI to show only relevant information based on the current user, which creates less confusion for less experienced users and provides ease of access throughout a system.

### Adaptation vs. Adaptability

A semantic distinction is made between adaptation, referring to system-driven changes for personalisation, and adaptability, referring to user-driven changes, where adaptation is automatic, whereas adaptability is not.

### Applications

One of the common place implementations of an AUI is in the medical industry, where the AUI is used to differentiate and specify which information should be shown to which type of user.

### Related Concepts

The search results also revealed related concepts like **adaptive hypermedia**, which tailors what the user is offered based on a model of the user's goals, preferences and knowledge, thus providing links or content most appropriate to the current user, and **adaptive web design**, which focuses on serving different versions of web pages for different devices.

Moran - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_P._Moran"}]

## Human-Computer Interaction (HCI)

Based on the search results, here's an overview of human-computer interaction:

### Definition
Human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems.(no content)Research in HCI covers the design and the use of computer technology, which focuses on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

### Academic Definition
The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".

### Interdisciplinary Nature
HCI studies a human and a machine in communication, drawing from supporting knowledge on both sides. On the machine side, techniques in computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages, and development environments are relevant. On the human side, communication theory, graphic and industrial design disciplines, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, social psychology, and human factors are relevant.

### Key Aspects
A key aspect of HCI is user satisfaction, also referred to as End-User Computing Satisfaction.(no content)The interface between humans and computers is crucial to facilitating this interaction.

### Interaction Modalities
HCI research encompasses various interaction methods including gesture recognition, which involves identifying and interpreting gestures made by users, and gaze detection, which involves tracking the movement of a user's eyes to better understand the user's attention, intent, or focus.

Human-computer interaction remains a vital field that bridges computer science with behavioral sciences to create more effective and user-friendly technology.

Moran - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_P._Moran"}]

## Human-Computer Interaction (HCI)

Based on the search results, here's an overview of human-computer interaction:

### Definition
Human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems.(no content)Research in HCI covers the design and the use of computer technology, which focuses on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

### Academic Definition
The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".

### Interdisciplinary Nature
HCI studies a human and a machine in communication, drawing from supporting knowledge on both sides. On the machine side, techniques in computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages, and development environments are relevant. On the human side, communication theory, graphic and industrial design disciplines, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, social psychology, and human factors are relevant.

### Key Aspects
A key aspect of HCI is user satisfaction, also referred to as End-User Computing Satisfaction.(no content)The interface between humans and computers is crucial to facilitating this interaction.

### Interaction Modalities
HCI research encompasses various interaction methods including gesture recognition, which involves identifying and interpreting gestures made by users, and gaze detection, which involves tracking the movement of a user's eyes to better understand the user's attention, intent, or focus.

Human-computer interaction remains a vital field that bridges computer science with behavioral sciences to create more effective and user-friendly technology.

7. **Multimodal Interaction** - Multiple input/output modalities
8. **Data and Information Visualization** - Knowledge visualization methods
